docs.lead_paragraph: At a rally on Friday at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., President Obama got some of his loudest applause when he talked about a provision in the health care legislation that would allow adult children to remain on their parents' health insurance policies until the age of 26.

headline.main: New Health Bill Permits Children to Remain on Parents' Insurance

docs.abstract: The reconciliation bill would require insurers to cover the adult children of beneficiaries until age 26.
docs.snippet: The reconciliation bill would require insurers to cover the adult children of beneficiaries until age 26.

docs.lead_paragraph: "Surfing's New Wave of Aerialists" (05:12)It used to be about catching the wave. Now, for a new breed of surfer, it's about flying and twisting above it. "The future of surfing is apparently in the air," said Kelly Slater, a world champion. Competition is becoming more open to radical maneuvers. New rules are rewarding difficulty over consistency. As this video by Erik Olsen and Matt Higgins reveals, the stage was set in the late 1980s. Pioneer aerialists like Christian Fletcher employed the new moves but paid a high personal price. They were barred from competition and lost sponsorships. Mr. Olsen said he recognized that viewers have become accustomed to a high level of sophistication in surfing videos, adding that he was thankful to have found sources like Jon Steele and Elliot Leboe, "two fantastic filmmakers" who provided extra footage. The result is a dazzling exploration of surfing's past, present and probably airborne future. (K.B.)
docs.abstract: Surfers go airborne, men talk about love, reindeer cross Icelandic plains and a man without insurance sets his own broken ankle.
docs.snippet: Surfers go airborne, men talk about love, reindeer cross Icelandic plains and a man without insurance sets his own broken ankle.

byline.original: By ERIK OLSEN and KASSIE BRACKEN

docs.lead_paragraph: At his final rally before a historic House vote on health care legislation, President Obama compared the overhaul to Social Security, civil rights and Medicare, and he urged Congress to complete a journey that began with Theodore Roosevelt.

headline.main: Obama Rallies Support for Health Bill in Virginia

docs.abstract: President Obama spoke on health care to a boisterous crowd in Fairfax, Va., on Friday.
docs.snippet: President Obama spoke on health care to a boisterous crowd in Fairfax, Va., on Friday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Under a blazing morning sun that left reporters squinting on the East Front of the Capitol, Representative John Boccieri of Ohio on Friday morning became the latest Democrat to announce that he would support the big health care legislation after opposing the House bill in November.
docs.abstract: An Ohio representative who voted against the House health bill in November said Friday he will vote for the legislation this weekend.
docs.snippet: An Ohio representative who voted against the House health bill in November said Friday he will vote for the legislation this weekend.

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
docs.abstract: An attempt to encourage music buyers with $10 CDs, Democrats unveil the completed health care legislation, and other consumer-focused items from Friday's Times.
docs.snippet: An attempt to encourage music buyers with $10 CDs, Democrats unveil the completed health care legislation, and other consumer-focused items from Friday's Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate bill represents the best chance in decades of fixing this country’s broken health care system. House Democrats should approve it.

headline.seo: On the Verge of Health Care Reform

docs.lead_paragraph: A South Carolina case in which a teenager with H.I.V. had his insurance policy revoked is a reminder of why we need health care reform now, imperfect as it is.

docs.lead_paragraph: After warning that it would run out of money within weeks, Miami’s public hospital group has cobbled together a stabilization plan.

headline.seo: Plan Approved for Public Hospitals in Miami to Tackle Deficit
headline.main: Public Hospitals in Miami Tackle Deficit With Pain
headline.print_headline: Public Hospitals In Miami Tackle Deficit With Pain

docs.lead_paragraph: Arizona’s budget makes it the first state to eliminate its Children’s Health Insurance Program, leaving nearly 47,000 low-income children without coverage.
